title: Watch CNBC's full interview with National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett

rawLines.text: president Trump announcing a 90-day
pause on some tariffs excluding China
joining us now with more national
economic council director uh Kevin
Hasset who all along I think we we we
divided people up into the negotiators
that that was Bessant and uh you're
going to probably won't like this that
was Bessant and Elon and I would say you
and then we had the the stand firm no
negotiators and that was maybe the
commerce secretary uh and maybe Peter
Navaro looks like something that you
said earlier in the week Kevin that that
sort of got I don't know circulated as
fact instead of fiction That was like a
market check yesterday It happened and
indeed 3,000 points
Well first of all I don't really like
the characterization that we're divided
amongst teams In fact I would say that
the person who right at the final minute
uh was with the president when the
president decided to do the pause that
we had been talking about all along was
uh Secretary Lutnik Secretary Lutnik and
Secretary Bessett were in the room for
the final call with the president And I
think that's a nice clarification about
how we're not on different teams Warren
waits will be boys according to Carolyn
Levit But you are you not on X you
didn't I I'm still don't get anything
except uh talk about that um that
whatever you want to call it that food
fight between Elon Musk and Ron Varro
Peter Well well well as you know that
that I practice a martial art called
Iikido where basically what you try to
do is redirect negative energy so that
it works against the guy and doesn't
turn it into an allout scuffle And I
think verbal iikido is a better choice
It's a better choice So Kevin is a
better choice for people I characterize
it as a as the art of the deal on one
side and hitting your head against the
wall until you know because it feels so
good when you stop and that the actual
what happened yesterday was somewhere uh
in the middle I guess you'd say it was
all art of the deal All that this was
the the plan all along to to go China
into being isolated
Well I I think that what's been going on
all along is the president recognizes
that in order to get the big change that
we need for America's workers Like these
are really fundamental changes that
we're talking about that we need to
create enough pressure on our trading
partners that things that American
presidents have been asking for for the
last decades uh are actually offered at
the table I can say that I was on a call
with the Swiss president yesterday with
President Trump We've got a whole uh
system set up through Susie Wilds and
the cabinet secretaries that we're
starting to have a meet meeting today
after lunch where we prioritize our
allies and other countries and decide
who who or what is going to visit and
when Uh but I can tell you that this the
amount of stuff that's coming to the
table uh came up really a lot you know
long before the market movements this
week And so it was looking like that
there had been enough action to get us
to the point where we should really
genuinely start negotiating And if you
go back and look you can see the
negotiation uh signals were out there
already even on that Monday where
somebody made a fake tweet that suddenly
said that I I was saying something that
ended up being kind of mostly true on
Wednesday And so so anyway I think that
everything was moving forward in an
orderly fashion And there's no no doubt
that the Treasury market yesterday uh
made it so that the decision that you
know it's about time to move was was
made I think with perhaps a little more
urgency but it was going to happen at
the moment anyway you you expect real
negotiations between over the next 90
days People say it's it's happy talk and
it's and in fact all these these trading
partners are going to be emboldened now
to not do anything because they know
that that the president's not serious or
or or he's going to blink So they can
just wait out and they got 90 days now
and they don't have to do anything I I
talked with Jameson Greer the US trade
representative uh yesterday just to get
an update on the number of countries and
and and of course saying you've got a
lot of countries calling that's one
thing right but you know they be could
be calling to say "How's the weather out
there?" But then having people really
begin negotiations to make offers that's
a different number That number is like
closing in on 20 There's a little bit of
discussion about exactly well did they
really make an offer but for sure
there's a bunch of offers that are
really sensible offers and they're
coming from our our top trading partners
and it's some of the most progress in
trade negotiation that I think probably
the most progress that we've ever seen
And so I think that this uh system that
the president set up to say "Hey we're
serious about negotiation We're serious
about reciprocity If you guys come down
we'll come down." To do that we've got
to have some negotiations The fact that
people started to send stuff we had two
deals almost closed as of last week
almost closed Getting them closed
requires the lawyers to work forever and
so on and so getting them closed by
yesterday was not quite going to happen
But yes there's a big inventory of deals
that are are right close to the finish
line All right that's interesting Kevin
how much of the decision was was led by
uh in terms of to pause yesterday was
led by the bond market and what you were
seeing there and anxiety on on that
front
my my view and you know I've been on the
show for 20 years right as I always just
shoot straight My view is that they're
very very close It could well be that
the announcement that came out yesterday
was going to happen anyway because there
were so many deals teed up There was a
discussion about whether a general pause
or a few deals that are just about
finalized are the way to move to the
next step and to make it clear to
markets that we're serious about the
strategy that we're following And I
think in the end everybody decided as a
team you know all the way from from uh
you know Peter Dvaro to whoever else you
think is on the other side uh agreed to
do it this way And I think you know the
fact that the bond market was telling us
hey it's probably time to move certainly
would have contributed at least a little
bit uh to that thinking but but it
wasn't the bond market that made a panic
move because there was a very systematic
wellplanned move that was just about to
happen that just turned out to be at the
same time Right Now the reason I ask
about the bond market Kevin is is as
this plays out over the next 90 days and
we all watch the bond market as well and
I imagine you you folks will too if we
see a spike in the bond market uh in a
similar way to what we saw you know in
the last 48 hours prior to the pause how
you think that changes the negotiations
or if it does at all and also how our
allies or folks who may not be our
allies or negotiating against us on
tariffs are going to be thinking about
that bond market Well I think that that
you can think about there being two
phases Phase one is going to be where we
demonstrate the truth that with the
guidance of Susie Wilds the chief of
staff's office that we've set up a
process so that these negotiations can
proceed in a very orderly well
thoughtout fashion with timelines and so
on and priorities And again there's a
big meeting about that with senior
cabinet officials today here at the
White House And then once we show you
well here's how we're doing it then I
think that'll be very uh reassuring for
markets because understand not only are
they serious but we can even see the
schedule and we can see the priorities
So the priorities make sense and then I
think that the second phase will be when
you start to see the actual deals and
see the characteristic of them and
they're saying oh not only are they
talking about it but they're delivering
and oh my that thing they delivered is
really great for American workers That
second phase is going to be much faster
than you might think because basically
we've got a few deals that we've been
working on ahead of this that are really
really well advanced Kevin I think
that's a big a big part of the question
what those deals look like I mean there
had been questions asked because even
renegotiating NAFTA took two years to do
Are are these just kind of straight
across the board bring tariffs down here
cut these non-tariff barriers Is it is
it a formula that that's kind of working
or is every country different well in
the end the the asks are going to be put
forward by the president uh guided by
the same trade team that got us to this
point And I think that the asks will be
sometimes extremely clear to the public
and sometimes they'll be quiet things uh
that involve things that people don't
even talk very much about involving
military matters or so on And so it's
all of the- above approach to make the
relationships between our countries much
stronger than they've ever been before
And I'm really highly excited about it
It's going to be a heck of a time And
when you talk about timing uh when when
I uh talked about well 60 days 90 days
uh the the book around the world in 80
days kind of ran into my mind and I'm
thinking well if we say 90 days let's
shoot for 80 days Uh and I think that
when I look at the schedules that we're
getting ready to debate and talk about I
think it's very doable Very doable Hey
Kevin we when we were still in in no not
negotiation uh mode we were hearing that
we could go to zero uh zero with a lot
of these countries but that doesn't cut
it There's so many other things in terms
of currency manipulations and you know
VATS and all these other protectionist
um things that that you can't that went
into the that crazy measurement that the
administration used to try to summarize
all of them using uh you know trade
deficits That seems like no way you
could get some of those deals done uh in
90 days Are we going to accept much less
than than what we were promised in terms
of getting rid of all the impediments uh
to trade i don't think there's any
chance that if Secretary Bessant or
Secretary Lutnik the two of the main
negotiators for this are going to go out
and come up with a deal and then they
show it to the president that if the
president doesn't think that it
satisfies his objectives for the
American people then those negotiators
on our team are going to hear from it
Boy I can tell you I I I've seen what
happens in the past of the previous
administration when deals are negotiated
that the president doesn't like He sends
them back to the drawing board until
he's ready to strike a deal that he
thinks is right people What are we doing
with China was that was that are we
isolating China to finally decouple
which is something that's that's a uh
you know something that's been talked
about but I don't know in practice
whether it's really possible or are you
do you expect them to come to the
negotiating table because most pundits
say that you know that she is backed
into a corner and there's no way um he's
going to come around at this point You
know President Trump has a strong
relationship with President Xi They've
had conversations in the past that have
been very productive Those conversations
haven't begun yet When they begin I
think is a decision that that President
Trump will will decide Uh and I don't
have any clarity on whether that's going
to be soon or later but I know that the
president uh has had a lot of progress
made a lot of progress in the past by
speaking directly with President Xi And
I'd be shocked if at some point that
doesn't happen We had we had Professor
Jeremy Seagull on earlier this morning
and he brought up a few questions about
this He said "Look first of all it takes
the markets time to recover from the
psychological damage that they've
experienced the last eight days." And he
also said he did not think that the
United States holds as many cards as we
think we do when it comes to negotiating
with China What would you what would you
respond to that
i think that that given the massive
trade deficit that we have that there
are really quite a few cards that are
held that are very difficult for uh
China to adjust to So think about it
right now that there are you know whole
container ships uh filled with stuff
that might be sitting in port in China
right now wondering what they're
supposed to do and then the factories
that you know reload the incoming
container ships wondering whether they
should shut down for a while because
they don't know where they're going to
be shipping this stuff It's an absolute
extreme disruption for the Chinese
economy right now that's come because of
repeated terrible behavior on their part
including aiding and abetting the
fentanyl trade And so I think China is
going to have to figure something out
And my guess is it's going to involve
reaching out to us and setting up talks
But but their economy is certainly right
now going through the kind of shock that
they probably never expected
Hey Kevin how does this whole pause
change the timeline to the extent it
does around the budget talks around
taxes uh that's something that you know
House Speaker Mike Johnson has talked
about he thought completing in the month
of May Uh given that I imagine these
talks are now going to play out in a
longer way in terms of the tariff piece
and potentially the revenue that could
come with that and I know that was
something that was important to the
administration in terms of thinking
about how to therefore construct the
budget I imagine we're now talking about
sometime in the summer Does this get
pushed to the fall where are we i don't
think the the very ambitious timeline
that the White House has signaled has uh
been changed at all If anything things
can even go faster Uh what's recall
happening is that the big six group
which includes Scott Bessant and me and
then the leadership of the House and the
Senate we've been meeting every week and
negotiating the tough negotiating things
so that both the House and the Senate
when they move forward that they're
moving forward in a kind of ratcheted
way so that they don't slip back And I
think that we're going to hopefully see
that this this week uh when the House
passes the Senate uh budget instructions
and then from there all of a sudden the
committees are going to start writing
the stuff And a lot of that stuff the
committee has been working on since last
summer And so I think that absolutely
the big beautiful tax bill is right on
schedule And then it is a technical
matter that I know that market
participants like to think about is that
now that we've got say $2 billion a day
in tariff revenue coming in That's a lot
of revenue that can help reduce budget
deficits should be good uh for bond
markets How does that influence the the
package and the bottom line is that what
will happen will be that the CBO when it
sees the revenue uh will start to adjust
the baseline for revenue to include uh
the the tariff revenue that comes in and
that will reduce the deficit It'd be
good for bond markets but but it won't
affect the overall numbers that they
agreed to It won't it won't count as as
a tax increase right it's just a
baseline Kevin I I appreciate the
perspective that it won't be part of the
the full CBO and um scoring That's
something that that we've talked to
Secretary Besson about but I always
thought that the administration and at
least some Republicans were thinking of
you know trying to include some of those
numbers at least in terms of how they
were going to sell the plan uh to the
public and to others when you you know
if we're talking about taking down uh
you know taxes on tips and things like
that And part of it was creating some
kind of permanence around those tariffs
so that you knew that that revenue was
also permanent If that revenue is not
permanent uh because there's still talks
going on that will therefore change the
dynamic with which you would negotiate
around the budget No Well what what I
mean to say Aaron is that uh the tariff
revenue if con Congress decides to write
into law the president's objectives then
we would of course celebrate that But
there's a plan right now that gets this
tax bill done you know before we all go
home uh for vacation in August Uh and
you know well before then and then it
doesn't require any tricky maneuvers
with the tariffs Uh the the the tea
right like the ball is on the tea and
and they can hit it and the tariffs are
going to be something that should make
the budget hawks really happy because
the deficit will be lower than they ever
dreamed possible but it won't affect the
reconciliation process So Kevin the the
10 you add the 10% this the tariffs on
uh I don't know Canada and Mexico and
and and you add in China and these are
the still the highest terrorist rates I
think we've had people say since since
holiday So is that permanent is this now
we we heard the other things are going
to be permanent It's hard to to really
gauge um what what's real and and and
what is sort of more posturing but do
you expect this to be a permanent
situation or this is fluid as well no I
I think everybody expects the the 10%
baseline tariff is going to be the
baseline and that it's going to take
some kind of extraordinary deal for the
president to go below there
in the way that I I don't know if if
history is ever going to really
um come down with with sort of the the
administration's spin on on how it all
happened you've seen some of the
articles that uh you know we that that
the president was watching some TV
yesterday and you know that that you
know saw different things happening that
finally forced his hand and that some of
his closest adviserss didn't find out um
you know exactly what was happening It
it just seems like a lot of this if
you're going to call it the art of the
deal should we just assume that that
it's a it is an art It's not a science
and you can get to this point and it was
all deliberate when it's all said and
done or are you just sort of being
buffeted by circumstance and finally
arriving at a a policy that affects the
entire globe frankly no Th this uh
policy was discussed at length with a
whole bunch of trade adviserss over many
many weeks Uh in the end the president
had multiple options to decide between
and he knew that he had to create
leverage to get people to the table to
begin negotiations He did that before
the final decision and the negotiations
lifted off uh like really crazy right uh
a couple days before market started
gyrating And so then the question is how
do we start to show that we're genuinely
going to have these negotiations and we
had a couple of deals that are close to
finished And we also uh had the idea
that we could have a pause And the
president decided to pick the latter
approach which was something that had
been studied all along all the way to
the beginning about like how do we go
from first let them know we're serious
to second getting negotiations that
actually delivered for the American
people And the president chose this path
and it was not something that he you
know thought up the last minute Right
But was it deliberate deliberate
overkill on the original the calculation
used for those very high tariffs that
allowed the United States you know to
cut it in half and have very high uh
tariffs Was that all part of the part of
the plan the the original AIPA was meant
to address the trade deficit which is
viewed as a national emergency and
having the tariffs be a function of the
trade deficit seemed like the logical
thing to do for the lawyers at the USR
And those numbers ended up being pretty
high And I think you know did the higher
numbers help get people to the table
help people understand the urgency of
what we're trying to accomplish i'm sure
they did Okay good Um Kevin thank you
Kevin Hasset thanks guys Great to be
here Okay hope to see you again soon
Thanks
